Authors: David C. Marshall, Thomas R. Buckley, Chris Simon
Title:
Accurate Branch Length Estimation in Partitioned Bayesian
Analyses Requires Accommodation of Among-Partition Rate Variation and
Attention to Branch Length Priors.
Abstract:
Molecular phylogenetic studies are making increasing use
of partitioned Bayesian analyses via software tools like MrBayes version
3. Data partitioning is important because, as long as the same
topology/history underlies all of the partitions, it addresses some of
the problems associated with the combination of data sets with
heterogeneous rates and eliminates the need to argue the validity of
tests that have been used to judge data combinability. In addition, new
studies indicate that data partitioning and the use of mixed models
often dramatically improve the fit of model to data without the cost of
overparameterization. While applying partitioned models to studies of
protein-coding mitochondrial data, we have found that analyses using
MrBayes may infer overly „long‰ trees if among-partition rate variation
(APRV) is not explicitly accommodated and if data from different
partitions evolve at different average rates.
